attributes.title: Peripherally inserted central catheter versus central venous catheter for intravenous access: a protocol for systematic review and meta-analysis
attributes.description: This is a protocol for a systematic review of intervention. The objectives are as follows: To assess the effects of peripheral inserted central catheter versus central venous catheter for intravenous access.

attributes.title: Considerations for Retaining Challenging Longitudinal Samples: Mental Health Symptoms and Contact Methods as Predictors of Retention among a Sample of Repeat and First-Time DUI Offenders
attributes.description: This is a pre-registration for the study "Considerations for Retaining Challenging Longitudinal Samples: Mental Health Symptoms and Contact Methods as Predictors of Retention among a Sample of Repeat and First-Time DUI Offenders". This study will examine whether psychiatric comorbidity is associated with levels of attrition and amount of effort required for follow-up in a sample of repeat and first-time DUI offenders. It also aims to determine how much contact is needed and which methods of contact are most effective in reaching this population. The attached pre-registration provides detailed information about the data set, sample, design, and analytic plans for this study.

summary.value: Background: Attrition can threaten the external validity of longitudinal studies. This threat is likely to be heightened among those with alcohol use disorders and criminal involvement, as many are transient due to treatment, incarceration, or other lifestyle factors. DUI offenders, in particular, often have substance use disorder(s), criminal history, and additional psychiatric comorbidity, which could create further barriers to follow-up. The current study examines whether psychiatric comorbidity is associated with levels of attrition and amount of effort required for follow-up in a sample of repeat and first-time DUI offenders. It also aims to determine how much contact is needed and which methods of contact are most effective in reaching this population. Methods: We attempted to follow-up with 464 first-time and repeat DUI offenders 6-12 months after the baseline wave of a study. At baseline, a subset of 353 of these 464 completed the screener module of the Computerized Assessment and Referral System (CARS; Keating et al., 2019) to screen for psychiatric disorders. These 353 had data available about whether they screened positive for 19 different disorders. For all 464, we recorded the number of days, number of contact attempts, and type of contact methods used to attempt each follow-up interview. For those who did not complete a follow-up, we also recorded the reason a follow-up was not completed. Results: Results will first address the overall amount of contact required to retain our sample. Then, we will determine if there is a difference in follow-up effort and attrition between repeat and first-time DUI offenders. Next, in the subset who completed CARS, we will analyze the relationship between comorbidity (i.e., number and type of positive screens for psychiatric disorders) and attrition and follow-up effort. Finally, we will examine whether different contact methods or timing of contact relate to attrition and efficiency of interview completion.  Conclusion: We will discuss the implications of these results for future longitudinal studies with challenging populations.

This threat is likely to be heightened among those with alcohol use disorders and criminal involvement, as many are transient due to treatment, incarceration, or other lifestyle factors. DUI offenders, in particular, often have substance use disorder(s), criminal history, and additional psychiatric comorbidity, which could create further barriers to follow-up. The current study examines whether psychiatric comorbidity is associated with levels of attrition and amount of effort required for follow-up in a sample of repeat and first-time DUI offenders. It also aims to determine how much contact is needed and which methods of contact are most effective in reaching this population. attributes.title: How malleable are students’ cognitive and non-cognitive skills? A natural experiment
attributes.description:
Without a doubt, one of the most significant changes that COVID-19 imposed on families’ everyday-life is the massive shift to online education. The Hungarian government decided to close all schools on March 16 due to coronavirus infection and has ordered a digital education work schedule , which is essentially homeschooling. Students have to stay at home, and teachers teach them by digital means. 
We focus on primary schools and investigate how COVID-19 affects students’ cognitive and non-cognitive skills through an online survey-cum-experiment.

q2.value:
H1: We hypothesize that over time a) students’ delay of gratification and family background will correlate more; b) the relationship between students’ cognitive performance  and family background will become stronger; c) the ability to delay gratification will predict better students’ cognitive performance.

H2: We hypothesize that over time students’ subject-specific comparative academic self-concept will increase.

H3: We hypothesize that over time a) students’ will be less generous to their classmates, and b) the difference between students’ lending behavior between a random classmate and schoolmate will decrease. We hypothesize that a better family background mitigates these effects.

H4: We hypothesize that students’ baseline ability to delay gratification and better family background will positively affect the willingness to answer the survey.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Before the outbreak of COVID-19 the principal investigator was running a randomized control trial with 2898 students (from grade 4 to 8) in 148 classrooms and 29 schools to influence students’ school behavior. The study was pre-registered on February 10, 2020, in the RCT register of the American Economic Association  and also has IRB approval and consent from the schools and parents. 

As part of this prior field experiment, we have collected teacher-reported data on students’ grades in the core subjects (Hungarian grammar [essentially writing class], Hungarian literature [essentially reading class], and mathematics). 

We have also measured students’ ability to delay gratification in the form of an incentivized question, asked before the treatment. The interviewer has shown students two different stickers and asked the student the following question: ‘Do you want to have one sticker now, or two stickers tomorrow? If you choose one sticker, I will give it to you now, but if you choose two stickers, you will get them tomorrow morning.’ We have coded each student’s (binary) decision, and this serves as a baseline.

We have used the following question to measure students’ family background: ‘How many books do you have? You should count the number of books you and your parents possess together. Please do not include your coursebooks and newspapers’ (answer categories: less than one shelf 0-50; one shelf ca. 50; 2-3 shelves (ca: 150); 4-6 shelves (ca: 300); 2 bookcases (ca: 300-600 books); 3 bookcases (ca: 600-1000 books); more than 1000 books).

Approximately 20% of students have valid reading test-score that was collected in the frame of a prior filed experiment in Spring 2018 . Another 20% of students have valid test-scores obtained from a national measure of basic competences in mathematics and reading comprehension (similar to the PISA Test, but measured on the whole student population).
The main goal of this research is to continue measuring the cognitive and non-cognitive skills of the students and assess its evolution through time. We plan to measure cognitive skills by grade-specific math exercises developed by the Hungarian Educational Authority. Our non-cognitive measures will include delay of gratification, academic self-concept, and social attitude. We will measure these skills in several waves until the end of the digital education work schedule. We plan to carry out the first wave in April 2020, and then each month, we would do a subsequent wave. The online survey is planned to take 25 minutes. 

We will measure students’ ability to delay gratification with a similar question that we presented above. The choice remains hypothetical if we do not receive enough funds to incentivize students’ choices. Instead of stickers, we will deploy wristbands. We will ask the following questions: ‘Do you want to have one wristband of your preferred color now, or two wristbands tomorrow? If you choose one wristband, I will give it to you now, but if you choose two wristbands, you will get them tomorrow morning.’ For those who choose a wristband today, we will pose the same question, but instead of two they now can get three wristbands tomorrow. With these questions, we will have a three-scale measure of delay of gratification, the students choosing a wristband today instead of three tomorrow being the least able to delay gratification. 

To gauge academic self-concept, we will use the widely adopted Eccles-scale. The Comparative ASC (CASC) evaluates students’ academic self-concept relative to their classmates. The following question will be asked separately for each of the three core subjects: “Compared to your classmates how good are you at [subject]?”, coded from 1 (“In the class, I am among the worst at [subject]”) via 4 (“In the class, I am average at [subject]”) to 7 (“In the class, I am among the best at [subject]).

We will measure social attitude with the following questions: ”Imagine that you are going to the zoo with some of your classmates. One of your classmates has forgotten to bring money for the entrance ticket. You have enough money for two entrance tickets. Would you lend your classmate the money for the entrance ticket?” The answer categories are Yes, No, and I do not know. We will repeat the same question, but instead of classmates, we will use schoolmates.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We will collect the data online. We will send a survey to the participants that they fill in online.

q11.value: N= 2898 students (from grade 4 to 8) in 148 classrooms and 29 schools

q12.value: Before the outbreak of COVID-19 the principal investigator was running a randomized control trial with 2898 students (from grade 4 to 8) in 148 classrooms and 29 schools to influence students’ school behavior. The study was pre-registered on February 10, 2020, in the RCT register of the American Economic Association (https://www.socialscienceregistry.org/trials/5442). In that preregistration there is a power calculation that reveals that the sample size is sufficient to have a good chance to detect if the intervention is effective or not. This argument carries over to this project as well.

question.value:
The main goal of this research is to continue measuring the cognitive and non-cognitive skills of the students and assess its evolution through time. We plan to measure cognitive skills by grade-specific math exercises developed by the Hungarian Educational Authority.

We will measure students’ ability to delay gratification with simple questions. We will ask the following questions: ‘Do you want to have one wristband of your preferred color now, or two wristbands tomorrow? If you choose one wristband, I will give it to you now, but if you choose two wristbands, you will get them tomorrow morning.’ For those who choose a wristband today, we will pose the same question, but instead of two they now can get three wristbands tomorrow. With these questions, we will have a three-scale measure of delay of gratification, the students choosing a wristband today instead of three tomorrow being the least able to delay gratification. 

To gauge academic self-concept, we will use the widely adopted Eccles-scale. The Comparative ASC (CASC) evaluates students’ academic self-concept relative to their classmates. The following question will be asked separately for each of the three core subjects: “Compared to your classmates how good are you at [subject]?”, coded from 1 (“In the class, I am among the worst at [subject]”) via 4 (“In the class, I am average at [subject]”) to 7 (“In the class, I am among the best at [subject]).

We will measure social attitude with the following questions: ”Imagine that you are going to the zoo with some of your classmates. One of your classmates has forgotten to bring money for the entrance ticket. You have enough money for two entrance tickets. Would you lend your classmate the money for the entrance ticket?” The answer categories are Yes, No, and I do not know. We will repeat the same question, but instead of classmates, we will use schoolmates.

H1: We hypothesize that over time a) students’ delay of gratification and family background will correlate more; b) the relationship between students’ cognitive performance (measured by the math test) and family background will become stronger; c) the ability to delay gratification will predict better students’ cognitive performance.

H1 predicts that the correlation between different variables will become stronger over time. On the one hand, we will calculate simple pairwise correlations at the differnt time points and we will check if there is a significant difference in the correlation coefficients. Moreover, we will run OLS regressions in which one of the variables will be the dependent variable and the other will be an independent variable and we will include additional controls, among them time. Moreover, we will have an interaction term involving time and the independent variable of interest. If the coefficient of the interaction term including a dummy denoting the time point when the data was collected and the independent variable turns out to be positive and significant, then it indicates that we cannot reject H1. For instance, concerning part a) of the hypothesis the dependent variable is students' delay of gratification, the main independent variable is family background and we expect to see a positive and significant coefficient for the latter variable. Moreover, if we include dummies for the time points of data collection and interact these dummies with family background, then we expect to see a positive and significant coefficient showing that family background has an additional positive effect on delay of gratification as time passes. 

H2: We hypothesize that over time students’ subject-specific comparative academic self-concept (CASC) will increase.

A paired Wilcoxon signed-rank test is suitable to see if H2 holds by comparing subsequent subject-specific CASC values of the participants. We will use also OLS regression where the dependent variable is the subject-specific CASC and among the independent variables we will have dummies for the time when the data was collected and we can see if the coefficients of these dummies is positive and significant and if it is growing in time. If it is the case, then we have convincing evidence that H2 holds.

H3: We hypothesize that over time a) students’ will be less generous to their classmates, and b) the difference between students’ lending behavior between a random classmate and schoolmate will decrease. We hypothesize that a better family background mitigates these effects.

We can analyze the first part of H3 with the same methods as H2. That is, we will run paired WIlcoxon signed-rank tests and also OLS regressions. For the second part (the effect of family background) we will use the OLS regressions and include the family background variable and we expect to see a negative and significant coefficient.

H4: We hypothesize that students’ baseline ability to delay gratification and better family background will positively affect the willingness to answer the survey.

We will use linear probability models and logit and probit specifications to see if H4 holds. The willingness to answer the survey will be a binary variable, hence the use of the aforementioned models,

q19.value:
We will consider p-values, the main criterion being if the p-value is less than 0.05.
Our hypoteses are directional, so we will use one tailed tests.

q20.value: By construction, our measured variables cannot have extreme values, so we do not expect any problem with outliers.

q21.value:
By construction of the online survey, participants can only proceed if they answer the questions so we do not expect to have incomplete data.
We will contact the sample that we have and possibly not everybody will complete the survey. We have a hypothesis (H4) on what factors and how affect the completion.

H2: We hypothesize that over time students’ subject-specific comparative academic self-concept will increase.

H3: We hypothesize that over time a) students’ will be less generous to their classmates, and b) the difference between students’ lending behavior between a random classmate and schoolmate will decrease. We hypothesize that a better family background mitigates these effects.

H4: We hypothesize that students’ baseline ability to delay gratification and better family background will positively affect the willingness to answer the survey.

attributes.title: Effect of estrogen and dietary sugar intake on food reinforcement

q1.value: Effect of estrogen and dietary sugar intake on food reinforcement in pre and postpartum women

q3.value: This is a secondary data analysis examining the relationship between dietary sugar intake, estrogen, and food reinforcement between pregnancy and the postpartum period. Estrogen has been related to a decrease in motivation for a sugar reward in animal models. Further estrogen has been shown to increase prediction errors in the nucleus accumbens. Together this suggests that estrogen is related to dopaminergic signaling and behaviorally this manifests as a reduction in the rewarding aspects of sugar. However, in the addiction literature, estrogen has been shown to increase motivation for illicit substances and alcohol. The differences between sugar and other rewards is not fully understood. During pregnancy, estrogen levels increases exponentially. This provides an interesting model to test the effect of estrogen on food reward and the effect of sugar intake.

q4.value: Aim1. To test the interactive effects of estrogen and added sugar intake on motivation for a reward, we will assess serum estrogen, percent added sugar intake from 2 diet recalls, and motivation (food reinforcement scale) from the PEAS dataset both in the pregnancy and postpartum period. We expect a significant interaction between added sugar intake and estrogen. Specifically we expect high dietary sugar intake will ablate the reward diminishing effect of estrogen during pregnancy (these women will show high pregnancy reward values, compared to low sugar intake).

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
This study was completed in 2016. It was a longitudinal observational study of women in and around the Chapel Hill area from 12 wks pregnancy through 1yr postpartum. Details have been published here.
Pregnancy eating attributes study (PEAS): a cohort study examining behavioral and environmental influences on diet and weight change in pregnancy and postpartum.
Nansel TR, Lipsky LM, Siega-Riz AM, Burger K, Faith M, Liu A
BMC Nutr. 2016 Jul 15; 2

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: While I have previously published on this dataset, it was a small subset of the total dataset. I have not looked at any summary statistics for the whole dataset outside of completion rates as the data was collected.

question.value:
Please see the attached file for total data collection procedures. 
For this analysis women will be excluded if:
They have less than 2 recalls in the pre and postpartum period.
They underwent sterilization in the postpartum period.
They reported postpartum depression.
They reported taking psychiatric medications or medications related to steroid hormones or related to body mass

data.name: Nansel et al. - 2016 - Pregnancy eating attributes study (PEAS) a cohort study examining behavioral and environmental influences on diet.pdf

extra.selectedFileName: Nansel et al. - 2016 - Pregnancy eating attributes study (PEAS) a cohort study examining behavioral and environmental influences on diet.pdf

question.value:
Experimental
Estradiol at 16-22 week pregnancy and 6 months postpartum 
Dietary sugar intake at baseline, 16-22 week pregnancy, and 6 months postpartum
Reinforcement measures (breakpoint and omax) change from baseline, 16-22 week pregnancy, and 6 months postpartum 
Covariates
Race/ethnicity 
SES
Parity 
BMI (change from baseline at 16-22wks pregnancy and 6mo postpartum)
Age

We will use a general linear model to assess the interaction of added sugar intake and estradiol concentrations on reinforcement. We run a series of models to assess the effect of the independent variables of interest:
1) baseline model (intercept only with covariates)
2) interaction model (interaction term with covariates)
We will assess differences between the two models using an anova. 
Estradiol and added sugar intake will be random intercepts.
All analysis will take place in R. p > 0.05. Bonferroni corrections

registration_responses.q8.question:
This study was completed in 2016. It was a longitudinal observational study of women in and around the Chapel Hill area from 12 wks pregnancy through 1yr postpartum. Details have been published here.
Pregnancy eating attributes study (PEAS): a cohort study examining behavioral and environmental influences on diet and weight change in pregnancy and postpartum.
Nansel TR, Lipsky LM, Siega-Riz AM, Burger K, Faith M, Liu A
BMC Nutr. 2016 Jul 15; 2
registration_responses.q12.question:
Please see the attached file for total data collection procedures. 
For this analysis women will be excluded if:
They have less than 2 recalls in the pre and postpartum period.
They underwent sterilization in the postpartum period.
They reported postpartum depression.
They reported taking psychiatric medications or medications related to steroid hormones or related to body mass

q12.uploader.file_name: Nansel et al. - 2016 - Pregnancy eating attributes study (PEAS) a cohort study examining behavioral and environmental influences on diet.pdf

registration_responses.q16.question: NA observational
registration_responses.q17.question:
Experimental
Estradiol at 16-22 week pregnancy and 6 months postpartum 
Dietary sugar intake at baseline, 16-22 week pregnancy, and 6 months postpartum
Reinforcement measures (breakpoint and omax) change from baseline, 16-22 week pregnancy, and 6 months postpartum 
Covariates
Race/ethnicity 
SES
Parity 
BMI (change from baseline at 16-22wks pregnancy and 6mo postpartum)
Age
registration_responses.q19.question:
We will use a general linear model to assess the interaction of added sugar intake and estradiol concentrations on reinforcement. We run a series of models to assess the effect of the independent variables of interest:
1) baseline model (intercept only with covariates)
2) interaction model (interaction term with covariates)
We will assess differences between the two models using an anova. 
Estradiol and added sugar intake will be random intercepts.
All analysis will take place in R. p > 0.05. Bonferroni corrections

attributes.title: Improving Institutional Communication in Times of COVID-19: Antecedents, Processes, and Consequences
attributes.description: The present research compares in a cross-cultural vein the effectiveness of institutional communications about COVID-19, depending on the emphasis these place on individualizing vs binding moral foundations. We will collect data in 25 countries (16 European) to allow for a good spread in the endorsement of different moral foundations, and to be able to control for cultural differences, which may also impact a priori perceptions of institutional trustworthiness. We will examine responses to different institutional communication strategies about COVID-19 in terms of compliance with the directives and willingness to display prosocial behaviors. We consider the interplay between individual endorsement of individualizing vs. binding moral foundations, and message framing (appealing to individualizing vs. binding moral foundations) while correcting for cross-national differences (in terms of individualism and collectivism). We further aim to understand whether the fit between individual disposition and the message framing impacts perceived reliability of the message and trustworthiness of the source, and further spills over prosocial attitudes and behaviors related to a number of social issues.

attributes.title: Ingroup Identification, Content of Social Contact, & Intergroup Inequality
attributes.description: This depository includes my dissertation to cover three studies. I aim to examine the effect of the content of social contact and ingroup identification on advantaged group members' attitudes and behaviors towards social inequality.

q2.value:
Abbreviations
HC: Participants who in the condition of the high-level of ingroup identification and commonality-focused social contact 
HD: Participants who in the condition of the high-level of ingroup identification and difference-focused social contact
LC: Participants who in the condition of the low-level of ingroup identification and commonality-focused social contact 
LD: Participants who in the condition of the low-level of ingroup identification and difference-focused social contact
H+S+: The social policy that provides an advantage for both host and Syrian refugees.
HnS+: The social policy that provides an advantage only for Syrian refugees.
H+S-: The social policy that provides an advantage for the host but a disadvantage for Syrian refugees.
H-S+: The social policy that provides an advantage for Syrian refugees but a disadvantage for the host.

Hypotheses

1) HC will show greater perceived intergroup inequality than HD.
2) LD will show greater perceived intergroup inequality than HD.
3) LD will show greater perceived intergroup inequality than LC.
4) LC will show greater perceived intergroup inequality than HC.
5) HD will show greater ingroup fairness than HC.
6) HD will show greater ingroup fairness than LD.
7) LC will show greater ingroup fairness than LD.
8) HC will show greater ingroup fairness than LC.
9) There will be no difference between groups in terms of supporting H+S+.
10) LD will show the greatest support to HnS+. LC, HC, and HD will follow it, respectively.
11) HD will show the greatest support to H+S-. HC, LC, and LD will follow it, respectively.
12) LD will show the greatest support to H-S+. LC, HC, and HD will follow it, respectively.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

q5.value: Confederate workers will not know about hypotheses.

question.value: Between subject design with 2 factors (the content of social contact, and ingroup identification), and each variable has 2 levels (respectively, commonality-focused vs difference-focused and high vs low).

q7.value: I will use simple randomization, where a participant will be randomly assigned to one of the following conditions: commonality-focused contact & high-level ingroup identification, commonality-focused contact & low-level ingroup identification, difference-focused contact & high-level ingroup identification, or difference-focused contact & low-level ingroup identification. These four blocks will be equally sized. Randomization will be done with Qualtrics' randomization function.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: As in Study 1 of this project, participants will be recruited through the Sona System and social media accounts of my department. Student participants who meet the specifications will receive 2 bonus points. Non-students will receive 25 Turkish Liras. The incentive will be raised up to 50 Turkish Liras if the sample size is not reached at the planned time. Since I aim to reach a representative Turkish sample, I synthesized the demographic statistic documents of the Turkish Statistical Institute and the 2012-2014 World Value Survey of Turkey. All tables and data I used are attached as an Excel document. The final version that shows a-priori characteristics of the required sample is attached as a Word document.

data.name: A-priori characteristics of required sample - Study 2.docx

extra.selectedFileName: A-priori characteristics of required sample - Study 2.docx

data.name: Characteristics of studies that manipulate ingroup identification - study 2.pdf

extra.selectedFileName: Characteristics of studies that manipulate ingroup identification - study 2.pdf

q11.value: I plan to reach approximately 225 participants assuming that my manipulation will not work for all participants. My target sample size is 156.

q12.value: As in Study 1 of this project, I used G*Power to conduct a power analysis. I will run two one-way ANOVA, and one MANOVA with five outcomes. Firstly, to obtain effect size f, I explored previous studies that used the same or similar independents and outcomes. The most current research was Saguy & Chernyaik-Hai (2012, Study 1). I used partial-eta squared of one-way ANOVA that analyzes the association between content of contact type and perception of the hierarchy as legitimate because the most similar variables are these. First, I pretended that the partial eta-square was like an eta-square since the researchers did not report eta-square. To use this parameter in G-Power, I converted it to "effect size f" with using https://www.psychometrica.de/effect_size.html. The value is .3693. Second, because I will run two one-way ANOVA with per one outcome, I divided alpha to two. Third, I choose power as .85. Finally, the required sample size is 82. I repeated this process for MANOVA. Because there are no studies that analyze the association between the same or similar independent and outcomes, I chose an effect size that is between medium, as .06. Finally, the required sample size is 156. In conclusion, I need to observe a minimum of 156 participants' valid behavior. The protocols of G*Power are attached as a Word document.

q13.value: If I find it difficult to reach my participants with certain characteristics, for instance, if I discern that I cannot finish collecting data within 3 months after starting, I will collect data from people I can reach, not only from participants with predetermined characteristics.

question.value:
I will manipulate the followings: 

1) Content of social contact with two levels that highlights commonality or difference between advantaged and disadvantaged groups

2) Ingroup identification with two levels as low or high.

1) Unequal Social System Perception 
2) Ingroup Fairness 
3) Supporting different types of social policies. Social policies will highlight the following types:
a) It provides an advantage for both Host and Syrians (H+S+) 
b) It provides an advantage for only Syrians (HnS+) 
c) It provides an advantage for Host, but a disadvantage for Syrians (H+S-) 
d) It provides a disadvantage for Host, but an advantage for Syrians (H-S+)

The perception of the unequal social system between groups and ingroup fairness will constitute the attitude aspect of inequality between groups. In other words, the mean of these two scales will create the attitude aspect of inequality between groups. Social policies with five indicators (four of them mentioned above and the last one is total score) will constitute the behavior aspect of inequality between groups.

I will measure participants' supporting behaviors with four different types of social policies; however, I want to analyze a total score of the behavior of maintaining social inequality. Each of these measurements will be taken in a 10-point Likert type. The measure of support given by the participant to HnS + and H-S + type policies will be considered as an inverted item and the score will be reversed. I will average these two inverted scores and H + S- score. This final mean score will mean supporting social policies against Syrian refugees. In other words, this score will be an indicator of the behavior of maintaining social inequality.

I will run one-way ANOVA for two outcomes which are the perception of the unequal social system and ingroup fairness. I will run a MANOVA with five indicators of supporting social policies. All analyses will run with R, Jamovi, or JASP.

q18.value: There will be no transformation process for outcomes or other demographics.

q19.value: There is no inference criteria in this study.

q20.value: The data of participants who leave measurements of dependents, age, sex, the region where live, religiosity, and level of education empty will be excluded. I verify that no data will be excluded except this situation, including outliers.

q21.value: The data of participants who leave measurements of dependents, age, sex, the region where live, religiosity, and level of education empty will be excluded. I verify that no data will be created with the mean of series or no such methods will be used.

q22.value: Only for the purpose of exploration, I may compare the outcome measurements of any specific groups to see which outcomes differentiate. I verify that I will report it if I run these comparisons.

q23.value:
The manipulation of the content of social contact is adapted from Saguy & Chernyak-Hai, 2012, study 1. Also, outcome measurements except supporting social policies are adapted from Saguy's several studies that investigate the "irony of harmony".

For the manipulation of the ingroup identification, I have reviewed the studies published in top journals and that received a lot of citations. I attached a Word document covering these studies. Finally, I decide to use an adapted version of the manipulation method combining Ellemers, Spears, & Doosje, 1996, and Zuo, Chen, & Zao, 2018.

12) LD will show the greatest support to H-S+. LC, HC, and HD will follow it, respectively.

attributes.title: The effectiveness of Feuerstein’s Instrumental Enrichment Programmes: A systematic review
attributes.description: A systematic review of studies that have examined Feuerstein Instrumental Enrichment programmes with an aim to evaluate the effectiveness of the intervention in typically developing children and adults along with those having cognitive impairment of either developmental, genetic or acquired origin. Additionally, to gain an understanding of the quality of this research, to determine what research gaps there are and to identify methodological issues warranting attention in future research.

copyright_holders: Philippa Harris and Dr Jo Van Herwegen

q2.value:
1.	It is predicted that the studies in the existing body of research will not cover all developmental stages, and the current review will examine the gaps in the research regarding Instrumental Enrichment Programmes.
2.	It is predicted that the evidence for the effectiveness of the intervention is mixed and that the effectiveness is, related to the quality of the study design (including the length of intervention and quality of training of mediator). In order to combat this effect when evaluating the effectiveness, a formal quality assessment of studies will be undertaken. 
3.	We will examine what characteristics of Instrumental Enrichment programmes common to studies reporting greater effectiveness, including length of intervention, amount of training and quality of the mediator training and the population.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
The following databases will be searched:
•	PsycInfo
•	Pubmed
•	Scopus 
•	ERIC (EBSCO)
Other sources:
•	ProQuest Dissertations and theses
•	OpenGrey (Grey literature in Europe)
•	Google and Google Scholar (first 150 hits recorded, exact URL and date of access recorded)
•	Visually research of references lists 
•	Books will only be included if the studies within contain methodological sections and meet inclusion criteria.
Search Syntax:
•	Reuven Feuerstein AND
•	"Mediated Learning Experience" OR
•	"Instrumental Enrichment program*" OR 
•	"Instrumental Enrichment Basic program*" OR 
•	"Feuerstein intervention training" OR
•	"Feuerstein intervention program*"

Types of studies included:
•	Intervention designs- randomised control trials, non-randomised control trials and pre-post studies, case studies with more than one data collection point. 

Types of publications included:
•	Peer-reviewed articles (published and in press)
•	Dissertations 
•	Books will only be included if they have a methodical section and meet the other inclusion criteria.
•	Grey literature 

Time and Language:
•	Included: any studies from 1978 (When Feuerstein developed the Instrumental enrichment programme) to March 2020 that are published or in press.
•	Full texts must have been available in English.

q11.value: The sample size will comprise of a respresentative sample size of the total number of publications that meet the inclusion criteria.

q13.value: Studies from 1978 to March 2020 that are published or in press.

question.value:
Primary outcomes were cognitive and behavioural functions as measured by:
•	Cognitive: Standardised assessments (e.g. Raven’s progressive matrices) and non-standardised (e.g. teacher assessments).  
•	Behavioural: standardised assessments and non-standardised (e.g. teacher assessments).
Other information extracted included: the number of participants included, the age of the participants, the types of control group included, whether it is longitudinal etc, country, SES, ethnicity, groups means and SDs and effect size.

Teachers and parent’s beliefs and attitudes to Mediated Learning Experience, Instrumental Enrichment and Instrumental Enrichment Basic will not be reviewed.

To find strengths and weakness in current research examined and to aid future research descriptive statistics will be used (number of participants, ages, location of rearcher).  Means and standard deviations will be used to calculate overall effect size of the effectiveness of Feuerstein's Instrumental Enrichment programmes from each study.

q20.value: Since this is a sole researcher review (dissertation project) the screening and selection of studies process will not involve an independent reviewer and will be recorded using the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA flow diagram).   Potentially eligible studies will be identified by screening of titles and abstracts, then full texts will be located and screened by the researcher and those meeting the inclusion criteria will be selected.  Reasons for excluding studies will be documented.  Due to time restraints it will not be possible to email authors of papers for any necessary clarification.

registration_responses.q2:
1.	It is predicted that the studies in the existing body of research will not cover all developmental stages, and the current review will examine the gaps in the research regarding Instrumental Enrichment Programmes.
2.	It is predicted that the evidence for the effectiveness of the intervention is mixed and that the effectiveness is, related to the quality of the study design (including the length of intervention and quality of training of mediator). In order to combat this effect when evaluating the effectiveness, a formal quality assessment of studies will be undertaken. 
3.	We will examine what characteristics of Instrumental Enrichment programmes common to studies reporting greater effectiveness, including length of intervention, amount of training and quality of the mediator training and the population.
q4: No blinding is involved in this study.
